contextId.information: In the Bible, people are often spoken of as trees. People who delight in Yahweh's law can do all God wants them to do just as a tree that is planted by water produces good fruit. AT: "He will be prosperous like a tree ... fruit in its season" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He will be like a tree ... fruit in its season

contextId.information: The enemy is spoken of as if it were a city full of broken down buildings. AT: "Our enemies were destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The enemy crumbled like ruins

contextId.information: This speaks of the wicked person as if he were a lion. AT: "He hides while he waits for the weak to walk near him, the same way a lion quietly waits in the bush for the animal it wants to attack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He lurks in secret like a lion in the thicket

contextId.information: The "apple of your eye" refers to something that is valuable. AT: "Protect me as you would something most valuable and precious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Protect me like the apple of your eye

contextId.information: The writer feels pursued the way a lion hunts its prey (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: They are like a lion ... like a young lion

contextId.information: Yahweh's voice sounded like thunder. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh thundered in the heavens

contextId.information: The Psalmist says that Yahweh has given him strength that surrounds and supports him like a belt. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:030|18:32]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: put strength on me like a belt

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the sun's coming out as if it were a bridegroom. AT: "The sun is like a bridegroom walking joyfully toward his bride" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The sun is like a bridegroom coming out of his chamber

contextId.information: The writer speaks about feeling weak as if his strength were like a dry piece of pottery that can easily break. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: My strength has dried up like a piece of pottery

contextId.information: Lebanon is spoken of as if it were a young calf. This emphasizes that when Yahweh speaks, the power of his voice shakes the ground. AT: "He makes the land of Lebanon shake like a calf skipping" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He makes Lebanon skip like a calf

contextId.information: The writer says people have so forgotten him the it is as if he were already dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: as a dead man whom no one thinks about

contextId.information: The writer compares people with no understanding to horses and mules. Possible meanings are 1) the writer is speaking Yahweh's words to his readers, "You all must not be like a horse ... no understanding" or 2) Yahweh is speaking to the writer as though to a group of people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Do not be like a horse ... no understanding

contextId.information: "like behind a dam." The writer describes the creation of the sea as if God piles up all the waters together. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like a heap

contextId.information: The writer's enemies are spoken of as if they are chaff that is easily blown away. AT: "blown away by the wind like chaff" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: as chaff before the wind

contextId.information: These phrases describe the greatness of God's righteousness and judgments as if they were very high and deep. AT: "as high as the highest mountains ... as deep as the deepest sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like the mountains of God ... like the great deep

contextId.information: Evildoers are spoken of as if they are grass and plants that dry up and die in the hot weather. These two similes both mean they will die. AT: "die" or "come to an end" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: dry up as the grass ... wither as the green plants

contextId.information: The lives of people are spoken of as if they are as insignificant as shadows. AT: "Everyone disappears like shadows do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Surely every man walks about like a shadow

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh's lack of response as if Yahweh considered him to be a total stranger to him. AT: "I am like a complete stranger to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I am like a foreigner with you, a refugee

contextId.information: The writer compares the Israelites to sheep that people kill and eat. As sheep are helpless before those who kill them, so the Israelites are helpless before their enemies. AT: "You have allowed our enemies to kill us like they would kill a sheep and eat it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: You have made us like sheep destined for food

contextId.information: The writer compares people who will all die to a flock of sheep. Just as sheep cannot escape when the butcher decides to slaughter them, so men will not escape when it is their time to die. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Like sheep

contextId.information: Being safe and secure is spoken of as being like a strong tree. AT: "I am strong in God's house, like a green olive tree" or "Because I worship in God's house, I am secure like a green olive tree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I am like a green olive tree in God's house

contextId.information: The wicked things people say are spoken of as if they were poison. AT: "Their wicked words cause trouble as a snake's poison harms people" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Their poison is like a snake's poison

contextId.information: No longer existing is spoken of as melting and disappearing. AT: "Let the wicked vanish like a snail that melts and no longer exists" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Let them be like a snail that melts and passes away

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of his enemies threatening to attack people as if they were dogs howling, growling, or barking at people. AT: "they threaten to attack people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: they howl like dogs

contextId.information: Here the writer speaks of knowing and worshiping God as being more satisfying than eating a good meal. AT: "I will be happier than a person who eats a meal of fat and choice food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: It will be as if I ate a meal of marrow and fatness

contextId.information: The writer speaks of his enemies' tongues as if they were as sharp as swords. Here "tongues" represents the harsh words that the enemies speak. AT: "The harsh things that they say hurt me like a sharp sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: They have sharpened their tongues like swords

contextId.information: The king will be good, and he will do good things for his people as if he were rain doing good for freshly cut grass. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: May he come down like rain on the mown grass

contextId.information: "like the cedar trees in Lebanon." These trees were beautiful and had wood that was good for building. The meaning of this can be made clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: like Lebanon

contextId.information: This simile compares God's people to a flock of animals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: You led your people like a flock

contextId.information: The writer speaks about the Israelites as if they were sheep. This means God cared for and protected the people like a shepherd does his sheep. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like sheep ... like a flock

contextId.information: "high, like the heavens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like the heavens

contextId.information: The writer compares God's "angry actions" and "terrifying deeds" to a flood of water. AT: "All day long they threaten to destroy me like a flood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: They surround me like water all the day long

contextId.information: God compares David's rule as king to the moon to emphasize that someone from David's descendants will always rule as king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: forever like the moon

contextId.information: This compares evil people to grass, which grows quickly and in many places. AT: "When evil people appear quickly and seem to be everywhere, like grass" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: When the wicked sprout like the grass

contextId.information: Possible meanings are that righteous people will be like a healthy palm tree because they will 1) be strong or 2) live for long time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The righteous will flourish like the palm tree

contextId.information: "The mountains are unable to stand as Yahweh comes near" or "The mountains crumble in Yahweh's presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The mountains melt like wax before Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "my days" refers to the author's life and the idea of "smoke" is something that quickly disappears. AT: "my life passes away quickly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: my days pass away like smoke

contextId.information: He compares his loneliness to that of a  pelican, which is often seem alone instead of with other birds. AT: "I am lonely and despised like a pelican in the wilderness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I am like a pelican of the wilderness

contextId.information: The writer compares himself to a bird to emphasize his feeling of loneliness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I lie awake like a solitary bird

contextId.information: David would have sat in ashes as an act of mourning, therefore ashes would have fallen on his food. AT: "I eat ashes like I eat bread" or "As I mourn, ashes fall on the bread that I eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I eat ashes like bread

contextId.information: David compares his time left to live on earth to a fading shadow. AT: "My time to remain alive is short like an evening shadow that will soon be gone" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: My days are like a shadow that fades

contextId.information: The simile compares the great distance between heaven and earth to the greatness of God's love for his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: For as the skies are high ... toward those who honor him

contextId.information: The distance between east and west is so far that it cannot be measured. In this simile, that distance is being compared to how far God moves our guilt away from us. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: As far as the east ... removed the guilt of our sins from us

contextId.information: In this simile, the length of man's life is being compared to the short length of time that grass grows before it dies. AT: "The length of man's life is short like that of grass" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: As for man, his days are like grass

contextId.information: These phrases continue to talk about flowers and grass. They compare how flowers and grass die to how man dies. AT: "The wind blows over the flowers and grass and they disappear, and no one can tell where they once grew—it is the same way with man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The wind blows over it, and it disappears ... where it once grew

contextId.information: Here the water that covered the earth is being compared to how a large garment is able to completely cover something.  AT: "You completely covered the earth with water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: You covered the earth with water like a garment

contextId.information: People wore their clothes everyday. David speaks of him always being covered with his curses like he is covered by his clothing. AT: "Let his curses be on him every day like the garment he wears" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: May his curses be to him like the clothes he wears to cover himself

contextId.information: A wineskin is ruined when it hangs for a long time in a smoke-filled place. The writer compares himself to a wineskin that has been ruined by smoke to emphasize that he feels useless. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I have become like a wineskin in the smoke

contextId.information: Slag is the waste or undesired leftovers in the process of refining gold or other metals. Yahweh removes the wicked people as if they were trash. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: You remove all the wicked of the earth like slag

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of his enemies dying and being few in number. They are compare to the little bit of grass that grows on the roof of a house and withers and is not enough to cut or bundle. AT: "May they die and may there be so few of them that they would be like the grass ... sheaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: May they be like ... sheaves

contextId.information: The goodness of unity among God's people is spoken of as if it were like the fine oil that was poured on Aaron's head. AT: "This unity is precious like the oil that was poured on Aaron's head"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: It is like fine oil on the head

contextId.information: Being ignorant and powerless is spoken of as being like idols, which cannot speak, see, hear, or breathe. AT: "Those who make them are stupid and powerless like their idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Those who make them are like them

contextId.information: "May the my prayer please you the way the sweet smell of incense pleases people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: May my prayer be like incense

contextId.information: The writer compares humans to these thing to emphasize how short their lives are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like a breath ... like a passing shadow

contextId.information: Yahweh scatters hail as easily as a person would scatter bread crumbs. AT: "He dispenses the hail easily, as if it were crumbs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He dispenses the hail like crumbs
